Kurosawaâ€™s Legacy : More Than Just Samurai Films

03/05/2021

Camila Hernandez surveys the diverse filmic landscape of one of the world's most renowned directors

Image by Curzon Film Distributors

By Sam Harding

â€œI do not believe that film is simplistic, but multifaceted. [It] should satisfy a wide range of people, all the people.â€ (An interview with Kyoko Hirano for CinÃ©aste, 1986)

Filmmakers are often boiled down to a certain style or a particular theme with which fans and critics can string their films together. But when we do this, arenâ€™t we underestimating directors and film creators by the very act of pinning down their entire body of work to a single convention? Recently, I caught myself doing this with the creations of the great Akira Kurosawa. When we hear that name, our instinctive connotations involve images of larger-than-life samurai on horseback against a murky, monochrome sunset or sunrise â€“ depending on which part of the fantasy film youâ€™re imagining. However, my favourite Kurosawa film has never been samurai-oriented, and, unfortunately, many of us look past the uncommon fact that Kurosawa also made non-samurai films which were never quite as successful as, for instance, the epic Seven Samurai (1954) or Yojimbo (1961).

In fact, no single theme or subject matter could ever accurately sum up Kurosawaâ€™s entire career.

As a storyteller, Kurosawa took a highly modernist stance for his era. Deeply invested in reframing the narratives of classical â€˜Westernâ€™ works, like that of Shakespeare and Dostoevsky, Kurosawa developed a visual culture of Japanese innovation and progression on the grounds of expansion and globalisation. Many movie-goers have elaborated on this process of â€˜writing backâ€™ as the directorâ€™s way of catalysing Japanese â€˜classical cinemaâ€™ into the global sphere â€“ the established commercial studio system of its Western parallel, Hollywood. Various critics have found both comfort and distaste in this â€˜classicistâ€™ label, for, as Russell insightfully notes: â€œthe classicism of Japanese cinema might in fact lie in its ambivalence and openness, as it eschews the subject-centred gaze of Hollywood for an aesthetic that has often been confused with modernism but is more accurately understood as the melodrama of modernity,â€ (Japanese Cinema in the Global System).

Kurosawaâ€™s stories have been invested in the beauty and barbarism of humanity, of lawlessness, not to mention desires, lovers, fears and clowns, letting no element of his examinations fall vulnerable to the abstract. Thereâ€™s a piercing bitter aftertaste that emblematises much of Kurosawaâ€™s work which emanates from failure, warped fates, and the ultimate indifference it is all met with.

As a historian, his profound involvement with details, costumes, and accuracy carved a certain hardened edge of realism at the core of his films â€“ including all of its inevitable baggage. Kurosawa had a prominent national presence in the Japanese media despite the controversial political overtones which drove the plot-lines in many of his most successful films: criticism of bureaucratic corruption, of traditional Kabuki theatre tropes, and the absurdity of Japanese â€˜face-savingâ€™, along with other ingrained social codes. His controversial cinematic presence made an impression among journalists of the 1950s-60s, yet, in person, he was an enigmatic figure who vowed to hold his tongue when asked about his own cinematographic and technical nuances.

The director was held accountable for this by being continuously cited as saying: â€œIf I could have said it in words I would have â€“ then I wouldnâ€™t have needed to make the picture.â€ (Kurosawa on Kurosawa, Donald Ritchie, 1964). Inevitably, this seemed to unsettle many intrigued writers and interviewers, since they found Kurosawaâ€™s ability to slip in and out of his private life particularly incongruent with the vivacious and violent liveliness of his artistic endeavours.

Seven Samurai (1954)

His first epic, acclaimed film which was dramatically cut for the West, Seven Samurai, holds a special, 4 hour-long place in Kurosawa fansâ€™ hearts. The tone is emphatically established from the introductory credits, which are accompanied by the pulse of foreboding drums that set a kind of rhythm for the frenzied stampede of horses in the opening scene.

The samurai in Seven are â€œdislocated, displaced, declassed, marginal people,â€ whom Kaplan also deems as â€œmen of action,â€ and whose accomplishments will â€œturn to dust unless the alliance between [samurai and peasants] progresses and develops.â€ (Kaplan, CinÃ©aste, 1979-80) Kurosawaâ€™s samurai are indeed lawless village-wreckers, instigators of sexual violence, thieves, yet, above all, flawed humans. Perhaps this all-encompassing humanity allows for Kurosawaâ€™s portrayal of these characters to diverge from that Westernised and romanticised image of hyper-honourable monk-like renditions of Eastern archetypes who take on an almost charismatic quality outside of Asian cinema.

The Bad Sleep Well (1960)

Kurosawaâ€™s murkier, cosmopolitan Hamlet, The Bad Sleep Well, is Kurosawaâ€™s take on American film noir, tackling a story of bribery and corruption which is crafted into a commentary on â€œthe power of big business,â€ as Higham in The Kenyon Review (1965) described it, to expose the corrupt boardrooms of post-war corporate Japan. Kurosawa, again, refuses to glamourise his subject, instead he brings to the forefront the festering corruption which emerges as a by-product of a corporate mindset that slacks off public responsibility, and an obsession with guilt-ridden submission to oneâ€™s superiors.

The 1960 film is Kurosawaâ€™s least-known adaptation of a Shakespearean text, since the samurai-oriented Throne of Blood (1957) and Ran (1986) far outweighed the former feature which is deemed the loosest adaptation of the three. However, it stood out to me as a particularly important film. Despite its deviations from its source text, The Bad Sleep Well successfully employs and elaborates on its themes of faÃ§ade and hidden realities to conjure the context of Japanâ€™s disillusioned social landscape and its search for a coherent identity in the post-occupation period.

Ikiru (1952) and One Wonderful Sunday (1947)

I think of Ikiru every time I pass a playground. Though it tackles a seemingly counterintuitive idea â€“ the poetics of bureaucracy â€“ Ikiru is one of Kurosawaâ€™s profoundly sentimental and existential pieces, wherein the central character comes to abandon his passive outlook on life whilst the surrounding characters are left in the shadows of his epiphany. One Wonderful Sunday is likewise simultaneously optimistic and pessimistic. With its backdrop of a dichotomised Tokyo of bomb-induced ruins and affluence, the latter film brings forgotten, simple joys to the limelight for an audience that seems to have exchanged them for the excess of a Westernised, materialistic world.

Kurosawaâ€™s rejection of â€˜simplisticâ€™ film, then, is made prominent throughout the directorâ€™s entire oeuvre; not only through his mastery of â€˜blockâ€™ scenes, canon text interpretations, his operating within social and cultural pressures, but by the scope which his artistry encompasses. His contribution to world cinema was more than just men with swords and/or suits, it was the vitality he exerted throughout various genres and how they are intimately related. Within every film, the set may be an enclosed or open tatami room; it may be a wide shot of a village street, a battlefield, or the seemingly static life of an old man. Yet, with Kurosawa, there is always a risk being taken â€“ a risk that many of us today still do not give him credit for.
